Abstract Abstract
This document defines a "RPKI Prefix List", a Cryptographic Message This document defines a "RPKI Prefix List", a Cryptographic Message
Syntax (CMS) protected content type for use with the Resource Public Syntax (CMS) protected content type for use with the Resource Public
Key Infrastructure (RPKI) to carry the complete list of prefixes Key Infrastructure (RPKI) to carry the complete list of prefixes
which an Autonomous System (AS) may originate to all or any of its which an Autonomous System (AS) may originate to all or any of its
routing peers. The validation of a RPKI Prefix List confirms that routing peers. The validation of a RPKI Prefix List confirms that
the holder of the listed ASN produced the object, and that this list the holder of the listed ASN produced the object, and that this list
is a current, accurate and complete description of address prefixes is a current, accurate and complete description of address prefixes

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
This document defines an "RPKI Prefix List", a Cryptographic Message This document defines an "RPKI Prefix List", a Cryptographic Message
Syntax (CMS) [RFC5652] [RFC6268] protected content type to carry a Syntax (CMS) [RFC5652] [RFC6268] protected content type to carry a
list of IP prefixes and an Autonomous System Number. The list of list of IP prefixes and an Autonomous System Number. The list of
prefixes describes the maximal set of prefixes that the Autonomous prefixes describes the maximal set of prefixes that the Autonomous
System MAY announce to any of its routing peers. The content is System MAY announce to any of its routing peers. The content is
signed by the holder of the RPKI private key associated with the signed by the holder of the RPKI private key associated with the
listed ASN. listed ASN.

'asID' field MUST be a subset of the AS Indentifiers present in 'asID' field MUST be a subset of the AS Indentifiers present in
the certificate extension. the certificate extension.
4. The Autonomous System Identifier Delegation extension MUST NOT 4. The Autonomous System Identifier Delegation extension MUST NOT
contain "inherit" elements. contain "inherit" elements.
5. The IP Address Delegation Extension [RFC3779] is not used in 5. The IP Address Delegation Extension [RFC3779] is not used in
PrefixList, and MUST NOT be present in the EE certificate. PrefixList, and MUST NOT be present in the EE certificate.
6. Operational Considerations 6. Recommendations for Creation of PrefixList Object
An AS SHOULD include all prefixes it originates in its PrefixList.
These would include prefixes it owns and the prefixes of BYOIP
customers. It is understood that some of these prefixes may have ROA
coverage and some may not.
There appears to be no need to include a maxLength in the PrefixList
object. The reason is as follows. Even if a prefix originated by an
AS (whether the prefix is owned by the AS owner or BYOIP) has a ROA
with maxLength (greater than the prefix length), typically only the
prefix and possibly some of its subprefixes (i.e., subsumed more
specific prefixes) are announced in BGP. The owner of the prefix
informs the AS operator (typically via a customer interface) about
the prefixes and subprefixes (if any) it intends to announce, and
only those prefixes/subprefixes SHOULD be included in the PrefixList.
Other subprefixes SHOULD NOT be included merely because they are
permitted by the ROA or its maxLength. This narrows the attack
surface for forged-origin subprefix hijacks which may be otherwise
wide due to the ROA maxLength (also see Section 8.4).
7. Route Verification: State Space and Outcomes
The state-space for route verification considering ROV and PrefixList
is enumerated in Table 1. Also, mentioned are the combined results
for each state from combining both verifcations. A RECOMMENDED route
selection policy is also mentioned in the last column of Table 1. A
network operator is free to select a policy that they consider most
appropriate. The use of the term "route is ineligible" in this
document has the same meaning as in RFC 4271, i.e., "route is
ineligible to be installed in Loc-RIB and will be excluded from the
next phase of route selection"
+=======+=========+===================+==========+============+
| Index | ROV | PrefixList Verif. | Combined | Route |
| | | | Verif. | Selection |
+=======+=========+===================+==========+============+
| 1 | Valid | Valid | Valid | Eligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 2 | Valid | Unknown | Unknown | Eligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 3 | Valid | Invalid | Invalid | Ineligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 4 | Unknown | Valid | Unknown | Eligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 5 | Unknown | Unknown | Unknown | Eligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 6 | Unknown | Invalid | Invalid | Ineligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 7 | Invalid | Valid | Invalid | Ineligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 8 | Invalid | Unknown | Invalid | Ineligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
| 9 | Invalid | Invalid | Invalid | Ineligible |
+-------+---------+-------------------+----------+------------+
Table 1
8. Problems Solved by PrefixList
There are four types of security vulnerabilities in BGP that the
PrefixList object helps solve. These are described below.
8.1. AS Abuse While Hijacking an ROV-Unknown Prefix
If AS A creates a PrefixList, it is protected in case an offending AS
X inserts AS A as the origin AS and hijacks a third party prefix not
covered by a ROA. The route will be ROV-Unknown and PrefixList
Invalid and hence considered ineligible by an RP (see row 6 in
Table 1). Thus, AS A protects itself from this form of AS abuse.
8.2. AS Abuse Together with a Bogus ROA
If AS A creates a PrefixList, it is protected in case an offending AS
X inserts AS A as the origin AS and announces a prefix for which AS X
has an RPKI certificate and creates a bogus ROA showing AS A as the
origin. The route will be ROV-Valid due to the bogus ROA but
PrefixList Invalid and hence considered ineligible by an RP (see row
3 in Table 1). Thus, AS A protects itself from this second form of
AS abuse as well.
8.3. AS Accidentally Strips AS_PATH and Mis-Originates Prefixes
A multihomed AS learns a route from eBGP neighbor and announces the
prefix to another eBGP neighbor as if it is being originated by it
(i.e., strips the received AS_PATH and re-originates the prefix).
This can be called re-origination or mis-origination (also see Type 5
route leak in RFC 7908). This problem has sometimes happened in
practice due to a malfunctioning route optimizer. If the affected
prefixes have ROA coverage, then ROV at a subsequent AS would detect
this anomaly. However, if the affected prefixes do not have ROA
coveage, then these prefixes will be ROV-Unknown and PrefixList
Invalid and considered Invalid by an RP (per row 6 in Table 1)
provided that the leaking AS has registered a PrefixList. Thus, a
leaking AS protects itself in the sense that when the leaks (mis-
originations) reach a neighbor AS that is doing PrefixList based
verification, they will be detected and blocked from further
propagation.
8.4. Attack Surface Reduction
Often a prefix owner includes more specific prefixes (using maxLength
or otherwise) in their ROA but has no plans to annouce some or many
of them. Due to this, they tend to create a larger attack surface
for forged-origin subprefix hijacks. However, they would notify the
operator of the AS serving them for origination about the prefixes
they do intend to originate, and the AS operator would include only
those prefixes in the AS's PrefixList. This helps to reduce the
attack surface for the forged-origin subprefix hijacks (per row 3 in
Table 1).
9. Operational Considerations
Multiple valid PrefixList objects could exist which contain the same Multiple valid PrefixList objects could exist which contain the same
asID. In such cases the union of address prefix members forms the asID. In such cases the union of address prefix members forms the
complete set of members. It is highly RECOMMENDED that a compliant complete set of members. It is highly RECOMMENDED that a compliant
CA maintains a single PrefixList for a given asID. CA maintains a single PrefixList for a given asID.
If an AS holder publishes a PrefixList, then relying parties SHOULD If an AS holder publishes a PrefixList, then relying parties SHOULD
assume that the list is complete for that originating AS, and the assume that the list is complete for that originating AS, and the
presence of any route with the same AS as the originating AS and an presence of any route with the same AS as the originating AS and an
address prefix that is not included in the Prefix List implies that address prefix that is not included in the Prefix List implies that
the route has been propagated within the routing system without the the route has been propagated within the routing system without the
permission of the originating AS. permission of the originating AS.
The construction of an 'allowlist' for a given EBGP session using The construction of an 'allowlist' for a given EBGP session using
RPKI PrefixList(s) compliments best practises [RFC7454] and rejecting RPKI PrefixList(s) compliments best practises [RFC7454] and rejecting
RPKI-invalid BGP route announcements [RFC6811]. In other words, if a RPKI-invalid BGP route announcements [RFC6811]. In other words, if a
given BGP route is covered by a RPKI PrefixList, but also is given BGP route is covered by a RPKI PrefixList, but also is
"invalid" from a Route Origin Validation perspective, it is "invalid" from a Route Origin Validation perspective, it is
RECOMMENDED to reject the route announcement. RECOMMENDED to reject the route announcement.
7. Security Considerations 9.1. Managing Expectations when Prefix Owner Splits a Prefix
A prefix owner with a prefix listed in the PrefixList of an AS may
one day decide to split its prefix and announce only a more specific
prefix (subsumed under the prefix) from the AS in consideration.
This operation needs to be managed gracefully applying the make-
before-break principle. When notified of the intent, the AS would
update its PrefixList to reflect the change. However, the updated
PrefixList would take some time to propagate to the RPs. So, the AS
would continue to announce the original prefix as well as the more-
specific prefix for the period of time necessary for the propagation
of the updated PrefixList. The period of time may be based on an
estimate of the propagation time such as its anticipated 95th-
percentile value. The prefix owner is kept informed of the resuting
wait times.
9.2. Managing Expectations when Prefix Owner Has A New Prefix
A prefix owner with a prefix listed in the PrefixList of an AS may
one day obtain a new prefix and wish to announce it from the AS in
consideration. The AS operator would recommend to the prefix owner
to create a ROA for the new prefix if not already done. The prefix
owner may or may not be RPKI capable. In any case, the AS operator
would update its PrefixList to add the new prefix. However, the
updated PrefixList would take some time to propagate to the RPs. The
AS operator would delay the announcemnt of the new prefix for a
period of time necessary for the propagation of the updated
PrefixList. The period of time may be based on an estimate of the
propagation time such as its anticipated 95th-percentile value. The
prefix owner is kept informed of the resuting wait times.
9.3. Why ROA Prefixes are not Simply Copied into PrefixList?
It may be argued that including everything from any applicable ROA
(including the optional maxLength if it exists) in the PrefixList
object makes the PrefixList more effective. One may reason that if
the prefix owner decides at a future date to annouce (from the AS in
consideration) more specific prefixes permitted by the ROA, the
PrefixList would be ready for it a priori. However, the benefit of a
pragmatic PrefixList, i.e., reducing the attack surface for potential
subprefix hijacks, is lost. So, there is a trade-off and it appears
better to opt for not copying prefixes from ROA into the PrefixList
and not including an optional maxLength in the PrefixList. Instead
include in the PrefixList only the prefixes requested by the prefix
owners for origination (typically via a customer interface). This
helps preserve the benefit of reduced attack surface. If a prefix
owner wishes readiness for future instantaneous annoucement of some
split prefixes under some circumstances, they can include them in
their ROA a priori, and simultaneosuly inform the AS operator to
include them in the PrefixList as well.
10. Security Considerations
Relying Parties are warned that the data in an PrefixList is self- Relying Parties are warned that the data in an PrefixList is self-
asserted by the AS holder. There is no implied authority from any IP asserted by the AS holder. There is no implied authority from any IP
prefix holder that grants the AS permission to originate a route for prefix holder that grants the AS permission to originate a route for
any prefixes. Such an authority is separately conveyed in the RPKI any prefixes. Such an authority is separately conveyed in the RPKI
as a ROA. as a ROA.
While a one-time-use EE certificate must only be used to generate and While a one-time-use EE certificate must only be used to generate and
sign a single PrefixList object, CAs technically are not restricted sign a single PrefixList object, CAs technically are not restricted
from generating and signing multiple different PrefixList objects from generating and signing multiple different PrefixList objects
with a single key pair. Any PrefixList objects sharing the same EE with a single key pair. Any PrefixList objects sharing the same EE
certificate cannot be revoked individually. certificate cannot be revoked individually.
